questions.text: What is the key difference between morphological and functional imaging?

options.A: Morphological imaging uses radiation, functional does not
options.C: Morphological imaging shows structure, functional imaging shows physiological processes
options.D: Functional imaging has higher spatial resolution

questions.explanation: The lecture explicitly contrasts morphological imaging (structure) with functional imaging (physiology and processes).

questions.text: Which modality is closest to the morphological end of the functional–morphological continuum?
questions.explanation: The continuum slide places radiography at the morphological end, far from tracer-based functional techniques.

questions.text: What principle enables functional imaging in nuclear medicine?
questions.explanation: One learning outcome is to "elaborate on the rationale of the tracer principle using selected examples."

questions.text: What is the tracer principle?

options.B: Using labeled molecules to visualize biological processes

questions.explanation: Slides on nuclear medicine describe tracers as labeled substances participating in metabolic processes.

questions.text: Which imaging modality is inherently functional without contrast agents?
questions.explanation: The slide "Inherent functional imaging" lists Doppler US as inherently functional.

questions.text: What physical effect is exploited by Doppler ultrasound?
questions.explanation: The Doppler slide shows frequency shifts caused by moving blood cells.

questions.text: What information does Doppler ultrasound primarily provide?
questions.explanation: Doppler US measures blood flow velocity using frequency shifts.

questions.text: Why are iodine-based contrast agents used in X-ray angiography?
questions.explanation: Slides state iodine-based agents "increase the X-ray attenuation and thus the contrast."

questions.text: Why can iodine contrast agents leave the blood vessels?
questions.explanation: The angiography slide notes their "small size enables them to eventually leave the blood vessels."

questions.text: Why do different organs show different contrast uptake curves in CT?

options.C: Parallel circuits in the circulatory system

questions.explanation: Slides explain that parallel connections in the circulatory system cause different uptake curves per organ.

questions.text: What distinguishes arterial from venous phase CT?
questions.explanation: The contrast-enhanced CT slides emphasize timing relative to contrast injection.

questions.text: Why is contrast timing critical in emergency bleeding CT?
questions.explanation: Emergency CT examples show arterial and venous phases to identify active bleeding.

questions.text: What does DCE-MRI primarily measure?
questions.explanation: Slides describe DCE-MRI as imaging vascularization and permeability.

questions.text: Why does contrast enhancement in the brain indicate pathology?

options.A: Brain tissue has no blood supply
options.C: Contrast agents cannot cross the blood–brain barrier

questions.explanation: Slides state that MR contrast agents cannot pass the blood–brain barrier; enhancement indicates disturbed permeability.

questions.text: Which contrast mechanism is exploited by fMRI?
questions.explanation: The fMRI slide explains Blood Oxygen Level Dependent (BOLD) contrast.

questions.text: What physiological change underlies the BOLD signal?
questions.explanation: Slides explain that deoxyhemoglobin alters relaxation properties and underlies BOLD contrast.

questions.text: Why is fMRI considered an indirect measure of neural activity?
questions.explanation: The lecture notes that BOLD changes are measurable seconds after neural activity.

questions.text: What distinguishes contrast-enhanced ultrasound from CT or MRI contrast?
questions.explanation: Slides state that US contrast agents are microbubbles that "do not leave vasculature."

questions.text: How do microbubbles generate contrast in ultrasound?
questions.explanation: Slides explain inelastic expansion/compression producing higher harmonics.

questions.text: Why can microbubbles be intentionally destroyed during imaging?
questions.explanation: The lecture states bubble destruction generates stronger short-term contrast.

questions.text: What is the main advantage of tracer-based nuclear medicine?
questions.explanation: Slides emphasize making metabolic processes visible using tracers.

questions.text: What is a radioactive isotope?

options.B: A nucleus with excess energy that decays

questions.explanation: Slides on radioactivity explain unstable isotopes undergoing decay.

questions.text: Which decay type is used in PET imaging?
questions.explanation: PET uses positron (beta plus) emission, as stated in the nuclear medicine slides.

questions.text: What physical event produces detectable photons in PET?
questions.explanation: Slides list annihilation as the key interaction for PET.

questions.text: Which isotope is most commonly used in SPECT?
questions.explanation: The isotope table lists Tc-99m as the most frequent SPECT isotope.

questions.text: Which modality detects single photons directly?
questions.explanation: SPECT stands for Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography.

questions.text: Why is spatial resolution typically lower in nuclear medicine?
questions.explanation: Slides discuss resolution limitations due to physics of emission and detection.

questions.text: Which interaction dominates gamma photon attenuation in tissue?
questions.explanation: Slides on radiation–matter interaction list Compton scattering as dominant.

questions.text: Why is functional imaging often combined with morphological imaging?
questions.explanation: The continuum and examples motivate combining function with anatomy.

questions.text: Which hybrid modality exemplifies this combination?
questions.explanation: PET/CT combines metabolic PET data with CT anatomy.

questions.text: What limits temporal resolution in functional imaging?
questions.explanation: Examples like fMRI show delayed physiological responses.

questions.text: Which statement best characterizes functional imaging?

options.C: Focuses on processes rather than structure

questions.explanation: The lecture consistently frames functional imaging as process-oriented.

questions.text: Why is quantitative analysis important in functional imaging?
questions.explanation: Functional measures require quantification to interpret physiological meaning.

questions.text: Which modality provides the most direct access to metabolic activity?
questions.explanation: PET directly images metabolic tracer uptake.

questions.text: What is the overarching goal of functional imaging?

options.B: Visualization of physiological and biochemical processes

questions.explanation: This goal is explicitly stated in the learning outcomes and illustrated throughout the lecture.
